metadata.title: African-American Migration and Mechanized Cotton Harvesting; 1950-1960

relevance.topic: African-American migration and mechanized cotton harvesting
relevance.relevance: The study examines the impact of mechanized cotton harvesting on African-American migration from the rural South, a key topic in labor displacement due to technological change.

design.sample_characteristics: African-Americans in the rural South, particularly in Arkansas, Louisiana, and Mississippi
design.geographical_focus: Southern United States, particularly Arkansas, Louisiana, and Mississippi

dependent_variables.displaced: Estimated 380,402 African-Americans displaced due to mechanized cotton harvesting

text_fragments: The mechanical cotton picker directly accounts for, at the most, 24% of the 1950-1960 African-American net migration from the South.
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study challenges the hypothesis that mechanized cotton harvesting was the primary cause of African-American migration, suggesting other factors also played significant roles.

historical_context.economic_conditions: Post-World War II economic adjustments, decline in cotton production
historical_context.institutional_context: Civil Rights movement, changes in southern labor market dynamics

outcomes.main_findings: The study finds that mechanized cotton harvesting accounted for a smaller proportion of African-American migration from the rural South than previously thought.
outcomes.conclusions: Mechanized cotton harvesting was not the main force behind African-American migration in the 1950s; other factors such as better opportunities in the North and reduction in cotton acreage also played significant roles.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The study suggests that the mechanical cotton picker was part of broader historical forces leading to the decline of the Old South and the relocation of African-Americans.
